questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: He is ……………… to live in a finer house.
questions.description: When enough is used as an adverb, it goes after the adjective it modifies.

questions.question: He used a hammer …………….. drive a nail into the wall.
questions.description: "In order to" is more emphatic than the infinitive.

questions.question: I was so bewildered …………….. I could not say a word.
questions.description: Note the pattern so…that. The above sentence can also be written as: ‘I was too bewildered to say a word’.

questions.question: …………….. the last day of our holiday, it rained.
questions.description: We use on with days.

questions.question: The house is burning. It is ……………… fire.
Will you lend me the scissors when you are finished ………… them?
I have a son and a daughter. …………… of them are good at maths.
questions.description: We use both to talk about two people or things. All and every are used to talk about more than two people or things.

questions.question: You can’t get there without ……………
questions.description: Singular countable nouns take an article or another determiner with them.

questions.question: What did you do with ……………. I lent you?
questions.description: We use ‘the’ when we say which one we mean.

questions.question: Do you like …………..?
questions.description: No article is used with a plural noun when we are talking about things in general.

questions.question: The teacher asked me to do the homework ……………
questions.description: In American English, over and again are both possible here. In British English, only again is used.

questions.question: We have lived …………… this street for ten years.
questions.description: In American English, on is used here whereas in British English, in is used.

questions.question: I am proud to be ………… the national football team.
questions.description: In American English, on is used here in British English, in is used here.

questions.question: One should love …………… neighbors.
questions.description: In British English, one’s is required whereas in American English, ‘his’ is possible here.

questions.question: It is important that she ……………
questions.description: We have used a special structure called the subjunctive here. In British English, the subjunctive is unusual and the structure with should + infinitive is used instead.

questions.question: I have never really …………… to know him.
questions.description: In American English, the past participle of get is gotten. In British English, the past participle of get is got.

questions.question: The birds have …………….. south for the winter.
questions.description: Flown is the past participle form of fly. To fly is to move in the air.

questions.question: I ………….. down and closed my eyes.
questions.description: Lay is the past tense of lie. To lie is to ‘be down’.

questions.question: I am not used to …………….. alone.
questions.description: Be used to can be followed by nouns or ing forms. It cannot be followed by infinitives.

questions.question: It took me quite some time to ……………… living in a big city.
I ……………… very hard last month.
questions.description: We do not use ‘used to’ to simply say what happened at a past time. That idea is expressed using the simple past.

questions.question: A minibus can hold ……………….. fifteen people.
questions.description: We use until to talk about time. To talk about quantity and distance, we use up to.

questions.question: Can you repair my camera if I leave it ……………… Friday?
questions.description: We use until to talk about a situation that will continue up to a certain moment. By is used to say that an action will happen at or before a future moment.

questions.question: Can I stay with you ……………. Monday?
questions.description: We use until to talk about a situation that will continue up to a certain moment. By is used to say that an action will happen at or before a future moment. Up to is used to indicate distance and quantity.

questions.question: You have to leave …………….. Tuesday midday at the latest.
questions.description: By is used to say that an action will happen at or before a future moment.

questions.question: The nearest restaurant is about half a kilometer …………….. the road.
questions.description: In this case both up and down can be used to mean ‘along’ with no difference of meaning.

questions.question: One cannot help ……………….. his courage.
questions.description: 'Cannot help but + infinitive' can be used with the meaning of ‘can’t help…ing’

questions.question: ……………… I become a billionaire, I will always lead a simple life.
questions.description: Even if refers to the future. Even though refers to the past. Even cannot be used as a conjunction.

questions.question: The man ………………. she married was an old friend of mine.
I have been working …………….. morning and I am getting tired.
questions.description: Since is normal with perfect and perfect continuous tenses.

questions.question: I ................................. him for the past month.
questions.description: Perfect tenses are preferred with the prepositions for and since.

questions.question: Professionals .......................... as doctors and teachers should show social commitment.
questions.description: The correct expression is 'such as'. Or you can use 'like'.

questions.question: The doctor, ........................... saw me in the morning, insisted that I should quit smoking.
questions.description: Both who and that can refer to people however, we cannot use that in non-identifying relative clauses. Here the commas indicate that the relative clause is non-identifying.

questions.question: I don't want to see ..............................
questions.description: In questions and negatives we use 'any' or 'anyone'.

questions.question: This is the house .......................... I was born.
questions.description: Where can mean in which.

questions.question: The house ........................... I was born in is made of clay.
questions.description: Where can mean in which.

questions.question: His failure didn't bother him .............................. the least.
questions.description: The correct expression is 'in the least'.

questions.question: She is ....................... a pretty girl.
questions.description: We use 'so' before an adjective we use 'such' before an adjective + noun.

questions.question: ............................... the people invited to the party didn't turn up.
questions.description: We use 'many of' before a noun with a determiner (the, my, this etc.)

questions.question: In accordance ............................ your request, we are sending you some samples.
questions.description: In accordance with is the correct expression.
